awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Dori Bejleri is "Algebraic geometry and moduli spaces." The host institution for the fellowship is Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Davesh Maulik.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project in algebraic geometry dealt with the question of classifying algebraic varieties; higher dimensional geometric shapes defined by polynomial equations. Such varieties form moduli spaces and the question of classifying these varieties amounts to understanding the geometry of these moduli spaces. 

The work done under this award laid the groundwork for an ongoing program to understand certain stable pair compactifications of moduli spaces of higher dimensional varieties. Under this grant, the PI introduced a new approach via twisted stable pairs which will lead to powerful new tools in the study of higher dimensional moduli. This includes a solution to the question of deformation theory of stable pairs when the coefficients are one and gluing morphisms describing the boundary of the moduli space.

The other aspect developed under this award is the study wall-crossing behavior for these moduli spaces: they undergo explicit birational transformations as one changes the parameters of the moduli problem. In many examples, including that of elliptic K3 surfaces and del Pezzo surfaces appearing in the papers supported by this award, these birational transformations interpolate between other compactifications furnished via twisted stable maps, Hodge theory, Geometric Invariant Theory, and K-stability. 

Under the support of this award, the PI gave over a dozen research talks to disseminate this work, organized several research seminars and reading groups, mentored undergraduate student research, and engaged with graduate students in research activities. The PI also taught several graduate courses on topics related to this research whose course material is online and available to the public. 


Last Modified: 10/10/2022
Modified by: Dori Bejleri

In many examples, including that of elliptic K3 surfaces and del Pezzo surfaces appearing in the papers supported by this award, these birational transformations interpolate between other compactifications furnished via twisted stable maps, Hodge theory, Geometric Invariant Theory, and K-stability.
